data.title: KeyBanc cuts rating on Comcast over bleak picture for broadband growth
data.description:
KeyBanc Capital Markets lowered its investment rating on Comcast (CMCSA) to "sector weight" from "overweight," citing a lack of catalysts following the company's third-quarter results.

The research firm said while broadband and mobile net additions were better than expected in Q3, it underappreciated the investment needed to achieve those results. It also noted that shareholder returns in terms of buyback are likely to decline going forward due to the investments for connectivity and platforms division, ramping NBA costs, and Versant spinoff.

KeyBanc pointed out that Comcast's broadband penetration rate has fallen for 14 consecutive quarters, and hence they need to see signs of stabilization before becoming more constructive on the company.

"Competitive concerns in broadband are likely to continue for the foreseeable future as telecom providers ramp fiber and FWA offerings over the next several years, where it's uncertain if and when Comcast will return to broadband subscriber growth," the research firm said in its analysis dated October 30.

"While CMCSA is inexpensive ... we think it's clearly trading there for a reason, as competitive concerns are elevated and investment is needed to hopefully return CMCSA to competitive positioning," KeyBanc said.

The research firm currently does not have a price target for CMCSA.

data.title: November and December could add more than 4% to the S&P 500 – analyst
data.description:
When the S&P 500 (SP500) has gained more than 15% by October’s close year-to-date, the months of November and December combined tend to extend the rally, according to Ryan Detrick, chief market strategist at Carson Group.

The S&P 500 (SP500) is currently 16.6% year-to-date. Carson Investment Research found that when the index gains more than 15% by the end of October, in 20 out of 21 years – with the exception of 2021 – the S&P 500 ends an extra 4.7% higher on average.

 

 

 

In 2024, even when at the end of December the S&P 500 (SP500) was -2.5%, the index still ended 3.1% for the months of November and December combined.

In 2019, the months of November and December added an extra 6.4% to the index, as at the end of October the index yielded 21.2%.

S&P-tracking ETFs: (SPY), (VOO), (IVV), (RSP), (SSO), (UPRO), (SH), (SDS), (SPXU)

data.title: LyondellBasell targets $1.1B in savings by 2026 amid signs of market recovery
data.description:
LyondellBasell Industries (LYB) announced Friday that it remains on pace to achieve $1.1 billion in cost reductions by 2026, crediting stronger demand trends and tight cost control for a quarterly performance that exceeded Wall Street forecasts.

The upbeat report pushed shares as much as 5.3% higher in trading, a sign of easing investor worries over soft demand and higher input costs, especially in Europe.

The Houston-based chemicals producer said its “cash improvement” initiative, introduced earlier this year, is expected to generate about $600 million in additional cash flow next year.

Profitability improved notably in its olefins and polyolefins Americas segment, helped by wider olefins margins and increased polyethylene sales following maintenance turnarounds at Texas plants. Management noted early signs of recovery in polyolefins demand, with U.S. polyethylene volumes rebounding after two sluggish years and European volumes climbing roughly 3% year-to-date.

For the third quarter, the company reported a net loss of $890 million, or $2.77 a share, compared with a profit of $573 million a year earlier. Results included about $1.2 billion in non-cash asset impairments and restructuring charges, mostly tied to its European operations. LyondellBasell (LYB) said ongoing regulatory pressures in Europe have prompted it and other producers to streamline operations and trim costs.

As part of a broader portfolio overhaul, the company has secured approval to sell four European assets and plans short maintenance shutdowns at plants in Germany and Texas to align with market conditions.

Looking ahead, management warned that typical seasonal softness and higher feedstock prices could compress margins in the fourth quarter. Still, the company expects recent capacity reductions in China, Japan, South Korea and Europe to help restore global supply balance.

On an adjusted basis, earnings were $1.01 a share, topping the analyst consensus of $0.80 compiled by S&P Global Intelligence.

data.title: Monolithic Power falls despite 'strong' Q3 and guidance, while analysts remain bullish
data.description:
Shares of Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) fell about 12% on Friday despite third quarter results and outlook beating estimates, and analysts showing bullish sentiments.

KeyBanc Capital kept its Overweight rating on Monolithic — which provides semiconductor-based power electronics solutions — and raised the price target on the stock to $1,300 from $1,250.

"MPWR reported strong 3Q results and 4Q guidance, which solidly beat expectations. Upside was primarily driven by Enterprise Data (+33% q/q, +4% y/y) and Industrials. Mgt [management] indicated 2H strength in ED [Enterprise Data] was driven by the ramp of new customers ((TPU)) and expects 30-40% growth in 2026, which we believe is conservative," said analysts led by John Vinh.

The analysts continue to expect strength in the second half of 2025 driven by share gains at Nvidia (NVDA) on B300 HGX and expect more meaningful growth in the second half of 2026 as Monolithic becomes the primary supplier on Nvidia's Vera Rubin.

"We're encouraged by these results and are slightly raising our ests [estimates] and our PT to $1,300. Reiterate Overweight," said Vinh and his team.

data.title: Cboe boosts sales growth guide after Q3 beat; starts portfolio realignment
data.description:
Cboe Global Markets (CBOE) on Friday raised its full-year guidance for organic net revenue growth, while lowering its expense outlook, after posting a double-beat on third-quarter headline results. Shares gained 4.6% minutes after the opening bell.

Meanwhile, the derivatives exchange said it's realigning its business portfolio in order to focus on core strengths and emerging growth opportunities. This includes starting a sales process for Cboe Australia and Cboe Canada; discontinuing U.S. and European corporate listings efforts; and lowering costs tied to the U.S. and European exchange-traded product listings businesses, Cboe Europe Derivatives and several of Cboe's smaller risk and market analytics units.

"Our Australian and Canadian equities businesses have consistently performed well and earned a reputation for innovation, reliability, and customer service. We believe these businesses are well positioned for future growth under new ownership," said Chris Isaacson, executive vice president, chief operating officer at Cboe Global Markets.

The company now expects FY2025 organic total net revenue to rise in the "low double-digit to mid-teens," a boost from the previous "high single-digit" target. Also for the year, Cboe Data Vantage organic net revenue growth is expected to be "high single-digit to low double-digit," vs. "mid to high single-digit" in the prior goal.

It also sees 2025 adjusted operating expense of $827M-$842M (midpoint $834.5M), down from $832M-$847M ($839.5M) in the earlier objective.

Q3 adjusted EPS of $2.67, topping the $2.53 average analyst estimate, climbed from $2.46 in Q2 and $2.22 a year before.

Q3 net revenue of $605.5M, vs. $592.4M consensus, drifted up from $587.3M in the prior quarter and $532.0M in Q3 2024.

Cash and spot markets revenue was $415.0M, down from $487.6M in Q2 and $434.1M in last year's Q3.

Data Vantage revenue rose to $162.1M from $158.3M in Q2 and $145.6M in Q3 2024.

Derivatives markets revenue of $564.6M compared with $527.6M in Q2 and $476.0M in Q3 2024. The 15% Y/Y increase was "propelled by multiple quarterly volume records set across the options business," noted Executive Vice President and CFO Jill Griebenow.

Total adjusted operating expenses were $210.2M, down from $213.3M in Q2 and up from $204.0M in Q3 2024.

data.title: Amazon’s earnings rally shines spotlight on the ETF market
data.description:
Amazon (AMZN) shares surged 11.5% on Friday after the e-commerce giant delivered quarterly results that topped Wall Street expectations.

The company beat estimates across net sales, profit, and subscription revenue, while its Amazon Web Services unit posted a robust 20% year-over-year gain. 

The upbeat report fueled optimism across the tech sector, lifting the Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) and boosting sentiment in numerous exchange traded funds heavily exposed to Amazon. 

The Seattle-based company is currently held in 617 ETFs, which collectively own more than 1.3 billion shares.

Outlined below are Wall Street’s 10 ETFs that have the largest allocation towards AMZN.

No. 1: Global X PureCap MSCI Consumer Discretionary ETF (GXPD), 34.77% allocation. 

No. 2: ProShares Online Retail ETF (ONLN), 24.46% allocation. 

No. 3: Fidelity MSCI Consumer Discretionary Index ETF (FDIS), 22.64% allocation. 

No. 4: Consumer Discretionary Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLY), 22.35% allocation. 

No. 5: Vanguard Consumer Discretionary ETF (VCR), 21.54% allocation. 

No. 6: VanEck Consumer Discretionary TruSector ETF (TRUD), 21.15% allocation. 

No. 7: Direxion Daily Consumer Discretionary Bull 3x Shares (WANT), 20.99% allocation. 

No. 8: ProShares Long Online/Short Stores ETF (CLIX), 20.33% allocation.

No. 9: VanEck Retail ETF (RTH), 20.20% allocation. 

No. 10: Roundhill AMZN WeeklyPay ETF (AMZW), 19.92% allocation. 

Amazon Performance and Ratings

  • 1-Month: +2.1%.
  • 6-Month: +20.8%.
  • Year-to-date: +1.5%.
  • SA Quant Rating: 3.48.
  • SA Analyst Rating: 3.94.
  • Wall Street Rating: 4.71.

data.title: WeRide granted license to operate driverless robotaxis in UAE
data.description:
• WeRide (WRD) has been granted a federal level license by the United Arab Emirates' Regulations Lab to operate fully driverless robotaxis.
  • The UAE’s Regulations Lab is a government initiative that develops and tests emerging and technologies to be deployed across the Emirates.
  • The federal level license allows WeRide’s (WRD) robotaxis to operate in the UAE commercially without an onboard safety driver.
  • China’s WeRide (WRD) had already been operating robotaxis in the Abu Dhabi since December 2024, including the May launch of driverless vehicles through a partnership with Uber (UBER).
  • There are currently more than 100 WeRide (WRD) robotaxis in the Middle East.
  • Shares opened more than 3% lower, reversing a premarket gain of 4%.
  • Source: SEC filing
